title: Primarily!
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"As we all know, a prime number consists of two factors only, 1 and itself, and a composite number consists of more than two factors. Therefore, it is logical to assume that the product of two distinct prime numbers is a composite number. So, if we multiplied the first 100 prime numbers together, the product would be a composite number. However, if we add the first n prime numbers together, sometimes we will get a prime number, but other times we will get a composite number."}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If we were to add the first 100 prime numbers, would the sum also be composite?"}]}]}

title: 16th Problem
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We know square roots of non perfect square number is always irrational.Which means digits come out randomly after the decimal point with infinitely long period.Now my question is, can you draw a line which has a length of an irrantional number(for example:√2)?"}]}]}

Proof: Writing "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"e"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for the base (though it really could be anything), it's easy to see that they are both equal to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"e^{(\log a)(\log b)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\quad\square"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This immediately gives us "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1700^{\log_A17}=17^{\log_A1700}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which means that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{1700^{\log_A17}-17^{\log_A1700}=0}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"As mentioned by another solution, it can be shown that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^{\log_y z} = z^{\log_y x}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so you don't even need any other information to know the result is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"That said, if you did want to find the roots as an exercise, then I'd recommend starting with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^3 - 6x^2 + 5x =  x(x-5)(x-1) = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Since the constant term of the second equation is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"45"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", it's worth verifying that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x-5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a root. Once you discover that it is, you can factor out the rest: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2x^4 - 11x^3 + 23x^2 - 99x + 45 = (x-5)(2x-1)(x^2+9) = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Simplify the above summation and give your answer to correct four decimal places."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Clarification:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[\cdot]"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" does "},{"type":"text","text":"not","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" denote greatest integer function; they are just square brackets. Also, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Gamma(n)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the "},{"type":"text","text":"gamma function","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" ."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Bonus Question:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" Find the value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle\sum_{x=1}^{1730} \left[\Gamma\left(\dfrac{1+2x}{2}\right)\Gamma\left(\dfrac{1-2x}{2}\right)\right]."}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"First note that  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1-\dfrac{1+2x}{2} = \dfrac{1-2x}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now we know the  "},{"type":"text","text":"Euler's Reflection Formula","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" : "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Gamma(n)\Gamma(1-n) = \dfrac{\pi}{\sin(n\pi)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" . So in this problem we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=\dfrac{1+2x}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" . So our summation changes to:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum_{x=1}^{1729} \dfrac{\pi}{\sin\left(\frac{(2x+1)\pi}{2}\right)} = \pi\sum_{x=1}^{1728} \dfrac{1}{\sin\left(\frac{(2x+1)\pi}{2}\right)}+\dfrac{\pi}{\sin\left(\frac{3459\pi}{2}\right)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=\pi\left[\dfrac{1}{\sin\dfrac{\pi}{2}}+\dfrac{1}{\sin\dfrac{3\pi}{2}}+\dfrac{1}{\sin\dfrac{5\pi}{2}}+\dfrac{1}{\sin\dfrac{7\pi}{2}}+\dots + \dfrac{1}{\sin\dfrac{3457\pi}{2}}\right] + \dfrac{\pi}{\sin\left(\frac{3\pi}{2}\right)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sin(\pi+x)=-\sin(x)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" , we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sin\left(n\dfrac{\pi}{2}\right)=-\sin\left((n+2)\dfrac{\pi}{2}\right)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and hence , "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left(\dfrac{1}{\sin\dfrac{\pi}{2}}+\dfrac{1}{\sin\dfrac{3\pi}{2}}\right)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ,  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left(\dfrac{1}{\sin\dfrac{5\pi}{2}}+\dfrac{1}{\sin\dfrac{7\pi}{2}}\right)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" , and so on till  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left(\dfrac{1}{\sin\dfrac{3455\pi}{2}}+\dfrac{1}{\sin\dfrac{3457\pi}{2}}\right)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ALL EQUAL ZERO!. Hence we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum_{x=1}^{1728} \dfrac{1}{\sin\left(\frac{(2x+1)\pi}{2}\right)} = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" .Also "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{\pi}{\sin\left(\frac{3\pi}{2}\right)} = -\pi"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" , hence our summation becomes:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=\pi \times 0 -\pi = -\pi\approx\boxed{-3.1415}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x + \frac{1}{x} = 1 \Rightarrow x^2 - x + 1 = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
The roots of this equation are 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = \frac{1 \pm i\sqrt{3}}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
This root can be written as 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x = \cos{\frac{\pi}{3}} \pm i\sin{\frac{\pi}{3}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Now let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = \cos{\frac{\pi}{3}} + i\sin{\frac{\pi}{3}} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{1}{x} = \cos{\frac{\pi}{3}}  - i\sin{\frac{\pi}{3}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We need to find "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^{1729} + (\frac{1}{x})^{1729}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Let it be equal to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Using de moivre's theorem("},{"type":"text","text":"de moivres theorem","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" ) we get:-
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S =  (\cos{\frac{\pi}{3}} + i\sin{\frac{\pi}{3}})^{1729} + ( \cos{\frac{\pi}{3}} -i\sin{\frac{\pi}{3}})^{1729} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S =  2 \cos{\frac{1729\pi}{3}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S = 2 \cos{(576\pi + \frac{\pi}{3})}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S = 2 \cos{\frac{\pi}{3}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S = 2 \times \frac{1}{2} = \boxed{1}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"First, we strike to solve the given equation. Rearranging it, gives
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+\frac{1}{x} = 1 \Rightarrow x^2-x+1=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
The roots of this equation are
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = \frac{1 \pm \sqrt{3}i}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
The above value should immediately ring a bell if we remember that the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^{rd}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" root(s) of unity are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{-1 \pm \sqrt{3}i}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Let us denote this by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\omega"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" that is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\omega = \frac{-1 + \sqrt{3}i}{2} \qquad \text{and}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\omega^2 = \frac{-1 - \sqrt{3}i}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
From this, we can immediately make out that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = -\omega, -\omega^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"But why did I represent "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in terms of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^{rd}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" root of unity?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The answer is simple. Since we are dealing with a large power ("},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1729"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"), expressing "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in terms of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^{rd}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" root of unity can help us simplify because of the well-known properties :
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1+\omega+\omega^2 = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\omega^3 = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Also observe that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1728 \equiv 0 \pmod{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"And thus, we finally left with computing"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned}
x^{1729} + x^{-1729} & = & (-\omega)^{1729}+(-\omega)^{-1729} \\
& = & (-\omega)^{1729}+(-\omega^2)^{1729} \\
& = & (-\omega)(-\omega)^{1728}+(-\omega^2)(-\omega^2)^{1728} \\
& = & (-\omega)+(-\omega^2) \\
& = & \boxed{1}
\end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Firstly, we see that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1729=1^3+12^3=9^3+10^3"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" Let's use "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"9^3+10^3=729+1000"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Now let's rearrange the given equation:
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+\frac{1}{x}=1 \Rightarrow x^2=x-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Then, note that
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^4=(x-1)^2=x^2-2x+1=(x-1)-2x+1=-x"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^8=(x^4)^2=(-x)^2=x^2=x-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^9=(x^8)(x)=(x-1)(x)=x^2-x=(x-1)-x=-1\\
\Rightarrow x^{81} = (-1)^9=-1\\
\Rightarrow x^{729}=(x^{81})^9=(-1)^9=-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^{10}=(x^9)(x)=(-1)(x)=-x\\
\Rightarrow x^{100}=(-x)^{10}=x^{10}=-x\\
\Rightarrow x^{1000}=(x^{100})^{10}=(-x)^{10}=x^{10}=-x"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Finally, we have
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned}
x^{1729}+x^{-1729} & = (x^{729+1000})+\frac{1}{x^{729+1000}}\\
&= (x^{729})(x^{1000})+\frac{1}{(x^{729})(x^{1000})}\\
&=(-1)(-x)+\frac{1}{(-1)(-x)}\\
&=x+\frac{1}{x} = \boxed{1}
\end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{aligned}
x + \frac 1 x & = & 1 \\
x^2 + 1 & = & x \\
x^2 - x + 1 & = & 0 \\
(x+1)(x^2-x+1) & = & = 0 \\
x^3+ 1 & = & 0 \\
x^3 & = & -1 \\
\end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Knowing that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1729"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a taxicab number, therefore "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"179 = 1^3 + 12^3 = 9^3 + 10^3 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \Rightarrow x^{1729} = x^1 \cdot x^{12^3} = x \left ( (x^3)^4 \right)^{144}  "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"With "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^3 = -1 \Rightarrow x^{1729} = x \cdot \left ( (-1)^{144} \right ) = x "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \Rightarrow x^{1729} + \frac 1 {x^{1729}} = x + \frac 1 x = 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If we analize the series we get to know after finding two values (x+1/x=1) and (x^2 + 1/x^2= -1)
Now the value of further series is difference of preciding two like
(X^3 + 1/x^3 = -2) difference of values of (x^2 + 1/x^2) & (x^1 + x^1)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Doing the same for upto (x^6 + 1/x^6 = 2)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We now get that from x^7 the value will get repeat and it attains the value of same as of (x + 1/x)
Which means the value x is changing as 
( X^n + 1/x^n = X^(6k+m) )"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Where n is the power of x can be written as 6k+m"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Where k and m depends on the number 
i.e. x^13
K=2 & m=1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For m=1 it will attain the value of 
(x + 1/x =1)
M=1.       1
M=2       -1
M=3      -2
M=4      -1
M=5.       1
M=6        2"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"now in given question 
N= 1729
Which can be written as 288*6+1
Here k= 288 and m= 1 
So for m=1 value is 1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I simply solved it like that:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^{1729}+x^{-1729}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+\frac{1}{x}=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^{1729}+\frac{1}{x^{1729}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"hence, [x=1]\"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since x+1/x= 1, then
x^2 + 1 =x 
and
1+1/x^2 =1/x."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Then since (x+1/x)^2 = x^2+1/x^2+2, using identities derived above we further derive
x^2+1/x^2+2 = x^2+1/x+1 = x + 1/x. Thus it also holds
(x+1/x)^3 =1."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since 1729 = 3^3 * 2^6+1. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Then It follows
(x+1/x)^1729 = ((x+1/x)^3)^3 * ((x+1/x)^2)^6 *(x+1/x)^1 = 1, based on previous identities."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This for me was quite easy to solve without using too much work. All you have to know is that there cannot be negative powers, and if there are, you make them denominators. Therefore you would have"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^{1729} over x^{1729}"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Simplify To get 1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Nice question
given
x+1/x=1
=x^2=x-1
Now
x^4=(x-1)^2=x^2-2x+1=x-1-2x+1=-x"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X^8=(x^4)^2=(-x)^2=x-1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X^9=x^8.x=(x-1).x=x^2-x=x-1-x=-1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X^81=(x^9)^9=(-1)^9=-1I"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X^729=(x^81)^9=(-1)^9=-1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X^10=x^9.x=-x"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X^100=(x^10)^10=(-x)^10=x^10=-x"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X^1000=(x^100)^10=(-x)^10=x^10=-x"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X^1729+x^-1729              =x^729+1000+1/x^729+1000"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=(x^729). (X^1000)+1/(x^729). (X^1000)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=(-1). (-x)+1/(-1). (-x)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=x+1/x"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"First, we experiment with "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+\frac{1}{x}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Square it. Since "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(x+\frac{1}{x})^2 = x^2+\frac{1}{x^2} + 2\frac{x}{x} = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":","}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"and we know that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" so it goes on and the answer is 1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
